soc.robot

Class SOCRobotBrain

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • soc.robot.SOCRobotBrain
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Sample3PBrain

    public class SOCRobotBrain
extends java.lang.Thread
    AI for playing Settlers of Catan. Represents a robot player within 1 game. The bot is a separate thread, so everything happens in run() or a method called from there.

    Some robot behaviors are altered by the SOCRobotParameters passed into our constructor. Some decision-making code is in the OpeningBuildStrategy, RobberStrategy, MonopolyStrategy, etc classes. Data and predictions about the other players in the game is in SOCPlayerTracker. If we're trading with other players for resources, some details of that are in SOCRobotNegotiator. All these, and data on the game and players, are initialized in setOurPlayerData().

    At the start of each player's turn, buildingPlan and most other state fields are cleared (search run() for mesType == SOCMessage.TURN). The plan for what to build next is decided in SOCRobotDM.planStuff(int) (called from planBuilding() and some other places) which updates buildingPlan. That plan is executed in planAndDoActionForPLAY1(), which calls buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard() and other strategy/decision methods.

    Current status and the next expected action are tracked by the "waitingFor" and "expect" flag fields. If we've sent the server an action and we're waiting for the result, waitingForGameState is true along with one other "expect" flag, such as expectPLACING_ROBBER. All these fields can be output for inspection by calling debugPrintBrainStatus().

    See run() for more details of how the bot waits for and reacts to incoming messages. Some reactions are chosen in methods like considerOffer(SOCTradeOffer) called from run(). Some robot actions wait for other players or other timeouts; the brain counts SOCTimingPing messages (1 per second) for timing. For robustness testing, the SOCRobotClient.debugRandomPause flag can be used to inject random delays in incoming messages.

    To keep the game moving, the server may force an inactive bot to end its turn; see SOCForceEndTurnThread.

    AI/Robot development:

    The bot can be sent debug commands to examine its state; see SOCRobotClient.handleGAMETEXTMSG(soc.message.SOCGameTextMsg).

    Extending this class is one way to begin developing a custom JSettlers bot:

    • Factory is SOCRobotClient.createBrain(SOCRobotParameters, SOCGame, CappedQueue), which can be overridden in a custom bot client like Sample3PClient
    • For a trivial example see Sample3PBrain
    • For more complicated extensions, extend strategy classes and/or SOCRobotDM, and override setStrategyFields() and any other factory methods needed.
    • Game option SOCGameOptionSet.K__EXT_BOT, which can be set at server startup using the command line or jsserver.properties file, can be used to send custom data or config from server to third-party bots
    For other methods/stubs/callbacks which can be extended, browse this package for protected methods. See Readme.developer.md for more about bot development.
    Author:
    Robert S Thomas

    • Field Detail

      • BOTS_ONLY_FAST_PAUSE_FACTOR

        public static float BOTS_ONLY_FAST_PAUSE_FACTOR
        Bot pause speed-up factor when SOCGame.isBotsOnly in pause(int). Default 0.25 (use 25% of normal pause time: 4x speed-up). Use .01 for a shorter delay (1% of normal pauses).
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • MAX_DENIED_BUILDING_PER_TURN

        public static int MAX_DENIED_BUILDING_PER_TURN
        If, during a turn, we make this many illegal build requests that the server denies, stop trying.
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        failedBuildingAttempts

      • BOTS_PAUSE_FOR_HUMAN_TRADE

        public static int BOTS_PAUSE_FOR_HUMAN_TRADE
        When a trade has been offered to humans (and maybe also to bots), pause for this many seconds before accepting an offer to give humans a chance to compete against fast bot decisions.
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_HUMANS

        protected static final int TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_HUMANS
        When a trade has been offered to humans (and maybe also to bots), maximum wait in seconds for responses: tradeResponseTimeoutSec. Longer than TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_BOTS_ONLY.

        Before v2.3.00 this was 100 seconds, which felt glacially slow compared to the quick pace of most bot activity.

        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_BOTS_ONLY

        protected static final int TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_BOTS_ONLY
        When a trade has been offered to only bots (not to any humans), maximum wait in seconds for responses: tradeResponseTimeoutSec. Shorter than TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_HUMANS.
        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • turnExceptionCount

        protected int turnExceptionCount
        Number of exceptions caught this turn, if any. Resets at each player's turn during TURN message.
        Since:
        1.1.20

      • counter

        protected int counter
        A counter used to measure passage of time. Incremented each second, when the server sends SOCTimingPing. When we decide to take an action, resets to 0. If counter gets too high, we assume a bug and leave the game (alive = false).

      • decidedIfSpecialBuild

        protected boolean decidedIfSpecialBuild
        During this turn, which is another player's turn, have we yet decided whether to do the Special Building phase (for the 6-player board)?
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • waitingForSpecialBuild

        protected boolean waitingForSpecialBuild
        true when we're waiting for our requested Special Building phase (for the 6-player board).
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • whatWeWantToBuild

        protected SOCPlayingPiece whatWeWantToBuild
        This is the piece we want to build now. Set in buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard() from buildingPlan, used in placeIfExpectPlacing().
        See Also:
        whatWeFailedToBuild

      • buildingPlan

        protected final SOCBuildPlanStack buildingPlan
        This is our current building plan.

        Cleared at the start of each player's turn, and a few other places if certain conditions arise, by calling resetBuildingPlan(). Set in planBuilding(). When adding to a buildingPlan, be sure to also set negotiator's target piece.

        SOCRobotDM.buildingPlan is the same Stack.

        Before v2.4.50 this was an unencapsulated Stack of SOCPossiblePiece.

        See Also:
        whatWeWantToBuild

      • whatWeFailedToBuild

        protected SOCPlayingPiece whatWeFailedToBuild
        This is what we tried building this turn, but the server said it was an illegal move (due to a bug in our robot).
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        whatWeWantToBuild, failedBuildingAttempts

      • failedBuildingAttempts

        protected int failedBuildingAttempts
        Track how many illegal placement requests we've made this turn. Avoid infinite turn length, by preventing robot from alternately choosing two wrong things when the server denies a bad build.
        Since:
        1.1.00
        See Also:
        whatWeFailedToBuild, MAX_DENIED_BUILDING_PER_TURN

      • ourPlayerTracker

        protected SOCPlayerTracker ourPlayerTracker
        Our player tracker within playerTrackers.

      • playerTrackers

        protected SOCPlayerTracker[] playerTrackers
        Trackers for all players (one per player number, including this robot). Null until setOurPlayerData(); see addPlayerTracker(int) for lifecycle info. Elements for vacant seats are null.

        Before v2.3.00 this was a HashMap. Converted to array to avoid iterator ConcurrentModificationExceptions during *LOADGAME* debug command.

        See Also:
        ourPlayerTracker

      • expectPLACING_ROBBER

        protected boolean expectPLACING_ROBBER
        True if we're expecting the PLACING_ROBBER state. playKnightCard() sets this field and waitingForGameState.

        In scenario SC_PIRI, this flag is also used when we've just played a "Convert to Warship" card (Knight/Soldier card) and we're waiting for the server response. The response won't be a GAMESTATE(PLACING_SOLDIER) message, it will either be PLAYERLEMENT(GAIN, SCENARIO_WARSHIP_COUNT) or DEVCARDACTION(CANNOT_PLAY). Since this situation is otherwise the same as playing a Knight/Soldier, we use this same waiting flags.

      • waitingForGameState

        protected boolean waitingForGameState
        true if we're waiting for a GAMESTATE message from the server. This is set after a robot action or requested action is sent to server, or just before ending our turn (which also sets waitingForOurTurn == true).

        For example, when playing a SOCDevCardAction, set true and also set an "expect" flag (expectPLACING_ROBBER, expectWAITING_FOR_DISCOVERY, etc).

        Special case:
        In scenario SC_PIRI, this flag is also set when we've just played a "Convert to Warship" card (Knight/Soldier card), although the server won't respond with a GAMESTATE message; see expectPLACING_ROBBER javadoc.

        See Also:
        rejectedPlayDevCardType, rejectedPlayInvItem

      • waitingForOurTurn

        protected boolean waitingForOurTurn
        true if we're waiting for a TURN message from the server when it's our turn

        protected boolean moveRobberOnSeven

      • waitingForTradeResponse

        protected boolean waitingForTradeResponse

        See Also:

      • tradeResponseTimeoutSec

        protected int tradeResponseTimeoutSec
        When waitingForTradeResponse, how many seconds to wait before we stop waiting for response to a trade message. Longer if trade is offered to humans, shorter if bots only: TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_HUMANS, TRADE_RESPONSE_TIMEOUT_SEC_BOTS_ONLY. Updated when waitingForTradeResponse is set true.
        Since:
        2.0.00

        2.0.00

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCRobotBrain

        public SOCRobotBrain(SOCRobotClient rc,
                     SOCRobotParameters params,
                     SOCGame ga,
                     CappedQueue<SOCMessage> mq)
        Create a robot brain to play a game.

        Depending on game options, constructor might copy and alter the robot parameters (for example, to clear SOCRobotParameters.getTradeFlag()).

        Please call setOurPlayerData() before using this brain or starting its thread.

        Parameters:
        rc - the robot client
        params - the robot parameters
        ga - the game we're playing
        mq - the message queue

      • addPlayerTracker

        public void addPlayerTracker(int pn)
        A player has sat down and been added to the game, during game formation. Create a PlayerTracker for them.

        Called when SITDOWN received from server; one SITDOWN is sent for every player, and our robot player might not be the first or last SITDOWN.

        Since our playerTrackers are initialized when our robot's SITDOWN is received (robotclient calls setOurPlayerData()), and seats may be vacant at that time (because SITDOWN not yet received for those seats), we must add a PlayerTracker for each SITDOWN received after our player's.

        Parameters:
        pn - Player number
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • setOurPlayerData

        public void setOurPlayerData()
        When we join a game and sit down to begin play, find our player data using our nickname. Called from SOCRobotClient when the server sends a SOCSitDown message.

        Initializes our game and ourPlayerData, SOCPlayerTrackers, etc. Calls setStrategyFields() to set SOCRobotDM, SOCRobotNegotiator, RobberStrategy, and other strategy fields,

        If you override this method, either call super.setOurPlayerData() or be sure to set all those fields.

      • setStrategyFields

        protected void setStrategyFields()
        Make the bot strategy selections, as part of getting ready to sit and play in setOurPlayerData(). Fields like game, ourPlayerData, and playerTrackers are set before calling this method.

        Selections or behavior within strategy classes may be influenced by getRobotParameters().getStrategyType().

        Fields set here:

        • decisionMaker: calls createDM()
        • negotiator: calls createNegotiator()
        • bseFactory: calls createEstimatorFactory()
        • discardStrategy
        • monopolyStrategy
        • openingBuildStrategy
        • robberStrategy
        When overriding this class: You may either set all those fields yourself, or call super.setStrategyFields() and then change the ones you need customized.
        Since:
        2.2.00

      • debugPrintBrainStatus

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> debugPrintBrainStatus()
        Print brain variables and status for this game to a list of Strings. Includes all of the expect and waitingFor fields (expectROLL_OR_CARD, waitingForGameState, etc.) Also prints the game state, and the messages received by this brain during the previous and current turns.

        Before v1.1.20, this printed to System.err instead of returning the status as Strings.

        Since:
        1.1.13

      • debugPrintTurnMessages

        protected static void debugPrintTurnMessages(java.util.List<?> msgV,
                                             java.lang.String msgDesc,
                                             java.util.List<java.lang.String> toList)
        Add the contents of this Vector as Strings to the provided list. One element per line, indented by \t. Headed by a line formatted as one of:
        Current turn: No messages received.
        Current turn: 5 messages received:
        Parameters:
        msgV - Vector of SOCMessages from server
        msgDesc - Short description of the vector, like 'previous' or 'current'
        toList - Add to this list
        Since:
        1.1.13

      • run

        public void run()
        Here is the run method. Just keep receiving game events through gameEventQ and deal with each one. Remember that we're sent a SOCTimingPing event once per second, incrementing counter. That allows the bot to wait a certain time for other players before it decides whether to do something.

        Nearly all bot actions start in this method; the overview of bot structures is in the class javadoc for prominence. See comments within run() for minor details.

        The brain thread will run until kill() has been called or its pinger stops, or it receives a SOCMessage.ROBOTDISMISS request to exit the game.

        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
        Overrides:
        run in class java.lang.Thread

      • handleGAMESTATE

        protected void handleGAMESTATE(GameState newState)
        Handle a game state change from SOCGameState or another message which has a Game State field. Clears waitingForGameState (unless newState is GameState.LOADING or GameState.LOADING_RESUMING), updates oldGameState if state value is actually changing, then calls SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.handleGAMESTATE(SOCGame, GameState).

        When state moves from GameState.ROLL_OR_CARD to GameState.PLAY1, calls startTurnMainActions().

        If overriding this method, please call super.handleGAMESTATE(newState) so game data is updated and startTurnMainActions() is called when it should be.

        Parameters:
        newState - New game state, like GameState.ROLL_OR_CARD; if 0, does nothing
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • resetFieldsAtEndTurn

        protected void resetFieldsAtEndTurn()
        Bot is ending its turn; reset state control fields to act during other players' turns.
        • waitingForGameState = true
        • expectROLL_OR_CARD = true
        • waitingForOurTurn = true
        • doneTrading = false only if robotParameters allow trade
        • counter = 0
        • clear/resetBuildingPlan()
        • negotiator.resetIsSelling(), .resetOffersMade(), .resetTargetPieces()

        Called only after endTurnActions() returns true. Does not call SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.endTurn(SOCGame).

        Since:
        2.0.00

      • considerScenarioTurnFinalActions

        protected boolean considerScenarioTurnFinalActions()
        Look for and take any scenario-specific final actions before ending the turn. Is called before endTurnActions().

        For example, _SC_PIRI will check if we've reached the fortress and have 5 or more warships, and if so will attack the fortress. Doing so ends the turn, so we don't try to attack before end of turn.

        _SC_FTRI can play a gift port from our inventory to place for better bank trades.

        NOTE: For now this method assumes it's called only in the SC_FTRI or SC_PIRI scenario. Caller must check the game for any relevant scenario SOCGameOptions before calling. Also assumes not waitingForGameState or any other pending action.

        Returns:
        true if an action was taken and turn shouldn't be ended yet, false otherwise
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • planAndDoActionForPLAY1

        protected void planAndDoActionForPLAY1()
        Plan what to do during PLAY1 game state and do that planned action, or end turn. Calls some or all of these strategy/decision methods, which third-party bots may override:
        • playKnightCardIfShould()
        • planBuilding()
        • buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard()
        • considerScenarioTurnFinalActions()
        • endTurnActions()
        If nothing to do, will call resetFieldsAtEndTurn() and SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.endTurn(SOCGame).

        Third-party bots may instead choose to override this entire method. If doing so, remember to account for the strategy/decision methods listed above.

        Before v2.4.50 this code was in the main #run() loop.

        Since:
        2.4.50

      • handleDICERESULT

        protected void handleDICERESULT(SOCDiceResult mes)
        Update game data and any bot tracking when dice have been rolled. Calls SOCGame.setCurrentDice(int). Third-party bots can override if needed; if so, be sure to call super.handleDICERESULT(..).
        Parameters:
        mes - Dice result info message
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • robberMoved

        protected void robberMoved(int newHex)
        Update game data and bot flags when robot or pirate has moved, including clear moveRobberOnSeven flag. Third-party bots can override if needed; if so, be sure to call super.robberMoved(..).

        Doesn't call server-only SOCGame.moveRobber(int, int) because that would call the functions to do the stealing. We just want to set where the robber moved. Server's MoveRobber message will be followed by messages like PlayerElement to report the gain/loss of resources.

        Parameters:
        newHex - New hex coordinate of robber if > 0, pirate if <= 0 (invert before using)
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • handleREPORTROBBERY

        protected void handleREPORTROBBERY(SOCReportRobbery mes)
        Update game data and any bot tracking when a player has been robbed. Calls SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.handleREPORTROBBERY(SOCReportRobbery, SOCGame). Third-party bots can override if needed; if so, be sure to call super.handleREPORTROBBERY(..).
        Parameters:
        mes - Robbery report message
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • tradeStopWaitingClearOffer

        protected void tradeStopWaitingClearOffer()
        Stop waiting for responses to a trade offer, no one has accepted it. Remember other players' responses or non-responses, Call client.clearOffer, clear waitingForTradeResponse and counter. Call SOCRobotNegotiator.recordResourcesFromNoResponse(SOCTradeOffer).
        Since:
        1.1.09
        See Also:
        clearTradingFlags(boolean, boolean), handleTradeResponse(int, boolean)

      • placeIfExpectPlacing

        protected void placeIfExpectPlacing()
        If it's our turn and we have an expect flag set (such as expectPLACING_SETTLEMENT), then call client.putPiece (game, whatWeWantToBuild).

        Looks for one of these game states:

        • GameState.START1A - GameState.START3B
        • GameState.PLACING_SETTLEMENT
        • GameState.PLACING_ROAD
        • GameState.PLACING_CITY
        • GameState.PLACING_SHIP
        • GameState.PLACING_FREE_ROAD1
        • GameState.PLACING_FREE_ROAD2
        Does nothing if waitingForGameState, waitingForOurTurn, ! ourTurn, or if state's corresponding expectPLACING_<piecetype> flag isn't set.

        If all goes well, server will reply with a PutPiece message to be handled in handlePUTPIECE_updateTrackers(int, int, int).

        Since:
        1.1.09
        See Also:
        buildRequestPlannedPiece()

      • rollOrPlayKnightOrExpectDice

        protected void rollOrPlayKnightOrExpectDice()
        On our turn, ask client to roll dice or play a knight; on other turns, update flags to expect dice result.

        Call when gameState GameState.ROLL_OR_CARD && ! waitingForGameState.

        Clears expectROLL_OR_CARD to false. Sets either expectDICERESULT, or expectPLACING_ROBBER and waitingForGameState.

        In scenario _SC_PIRI, don't play a Knight card before dice roll, because the scenario has no robber: Playing before the roll won't un-block any of our resource hexes, and it might put us over 7 resources.

        Since:
        1.1.08
        See Also:
        playKnightCardIfShould()

      • buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard

        protected void buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard()
                                        throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Either ask to build a planned piece, or use trading or development cards to get resources to build it. Examines buildingPlan for the next piece wanted. Sets whatWeWantToBuild by calling buildRequestPlannedPiece() or using a Road Building dev card.

        If we need resources and we can't get them through the robber, the Road Building or Monopoly or Discovery development cards, then trades with the bank (tradeWithBank(SOCBuildPlan)) or with other players (makeOffer(SOCBuildPlan)).

        Is called by planAndDoActionForPLAY1(). Call only if these conditions are all true:

        • ourTurn
        • planBuilding() already called
        • ! buildingPlan.empty()
        • gameState GameState.PLAY1 or GameState.SPECIAL_BUILDING
        • waitingFor... flags all false (waitingForGameState, etc) except possibly waitingForSpecialBuild
        • expect... flags all false (expectPLACING_ROAD, etc)
        • ! waitingForOurTurn
        • ! (expectROLL_OR_CARD && (counter < 4000))

        May set any of these flags:

        • waitingForGameState, and expectWAITING_FOR_DISCOVERY or expectWAITING_FOR_MONOPOLY
        • waitingForBankTradeMsg or waitingForTradeResponse or doneTrading
        • waitingForDevCard, or waitingForGameState and expectPLACING_SETTLEMENT (etc).
        • waitingForPickSpecialItem
        • Scenario actions such as waitingForSC_PIRI_FortressRequest

        In a future iteration of the run() loop with the expected PLACING_ state, the bot will build whatWeWantToBuild by calling placeIfExpectPlacing().

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if buildingPlan.isEmpty()
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • planAndPlaceInvItem

        protected void planAndPlaceInvItem()
                            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        On our turn, server is expecting us to choose a placement location for a SOCInventoryItem. Try to plan a location and send placement request command(s).

        Call only when these conditions are all true:

        • ourTurn && ! waitingForOurTurn
        • game state PLACING_INV_ITEM
        • ! waitingForGameState
        If the piece can be planned and placed, will set waitingForGameState and either expectPLAY1 or another expect flag, and send placement commands. If nothing could be planned and placed, does not set waitingForGameState.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if called with waitingForGameState true
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • handlePUTPIECE_updateGameData

        protected void handlePUTPIECE_updateGameData(SOCPutPiece mes)
        Handle a PUTPIECE for this game, by updating game data. For initial roads, also track their initial settlement in SOCPlayerTracker. In general, most tracking is done a bit later in handlePUTPIECE_updateTrackers(int, int, int).
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handleCANCELBUILDREQUEST

        protected void handleCANCELBUILDREQUEST(SOCCancelBuildRequest mes)
        Handle a CANCELBUILDREQUEST for this game.

        During game startup (START1B, START2B, or START3B):
        When sent from server to client, CANCELBUILDREQUEST means the current player wants to undo the placement of their initial settlement. This handler method calls SOCGame.undoPutInitSettlement(SOCPlayingPiece) and tracker.setPendingInitSettlement(null).

        During piece placement (PLACING_ROAD, PLACING_CITY, PLACING_SETTLEMENT, PLACING_FREE_ROAD1, or PLACING_FREE_ROAD2):
        When sent from server to client, CANCELBUILDREQUEST means the player has sent an illegal PUTPIECE (bad building location). Humans can probably decide a better place to put their road, but robots must cancel the build request and decide on a new plan.

        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handleTradeResponse

        protected void handleTradeResponse(int toPlayerNum,
                                   boolean accepted)
        Note that a player has replied to our offer, or we've accepted another player's offer. Determine whether to keep waiting for responses, and update negotiator appropriately. If accepted, also clears waitingForTradeResponse by calling clearTradingFlags(boolean, boolean).
        Parameters:
        toPlayerNum - Player number: The other player accepting or rejecting our offer, or ourPlayerNumber if called for accepting another player's offer
        accepted - True if offer was accepted, false if rejected
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        tradeStopWaitingClearOffer()

      • handleMAKEOFFER

        protected void handleMAKEOFFER(SOCMakeOffer mes)
        Handle a MAKEOFFER for this game. if another player makes an offer, that's the same as a rejection from them, but still wants to deal. Call considerOffer(SOCTradeOffer), and if we accept, clear our buildingPlan so we'll replan it. Ignore our own MAKEOFFERs echoed from server. Call SOCRobotNegotiator.recordResourcesFromOffer(SOCTradeOffer).
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handleREJECTOFFER

        protected void handleREJECTOFFER(SOCRejectOffer mes)
        Handle a REJECTOFFER for this game. watch rejections of other players' offers, and of our offers. If everyone's rejected our offer, clear waitingForTradeResponse.
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handleDEVCARDACTION

        protected void handleDEVCARDACTION(SOCDevCardAction mes)
        Handle a DEVCARDACTION for 1 card in this game. Updates game data. No brain-specific action, but bots can override this to observe and record dev card interactions. Ignores messages where SOCDevCardAction.getCardTypes() != null because those are currently sent only at game end.

        Before v2.0.00 this method was handleDEVCARD.

        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handlePUTPIECE_updateTrackers

        public void handlePUTPIECE_updateTrackers(int pn,
                                          int coord,
                                          int pieceType)
        Handle a PUTPIECE for this game, by updating SOCPlayerTrackers. Also handles the "move piece to here" part of MOVEPIECE.

        For initial placement of our own pieces, this method also checks and clears expectPUTPIECE_FROM_START1A, and sets expectSTART1B, etc. The final initial putpiece clears expectPUTPIECE_FROM_START2B and sets expectROLL_OR_CARD. As part of the PUTPIECE request, brain set those expectPUTPIECE flags in placeIfExpectPlacing().

        For initial settlements, won't track here: Delay tracking until the corresponding road is placed, in handlePUTPIECE_updateGameData(SOCPutPiece). This prevents the need for tracker "undo" work if a human player changes their mind on where to place the settlement.

        Parameters:
        pn - Piece's player number
        coord - Piece coordinate
        pieceType - Piece type, as in SOCPlayingPiece.SETTLEMENT
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • buildRequestPlannedPiece

        protected void buildRequestPlannedPiece()
        Have the client ask to build our top planned piece unless we've already been told by the server to not build it. Calls buildingPlan.advancePlan(). Sets whatWeWantToBuild, waitingForDevCard, or waitingForPickSpecialItem. Called from buildOrGetResourceByTradeOrCard().

        Checks against whatWeFailedToBuild to see if server has rejected this already. Calls client.buyDevCard() or client.buildRequest(). Sets waitingForDevCard or waitingForPickSpecialItem, or sets waitingForGameState and a flag like expectPLACING_SETTLEMENT (etc).

        Preconditions: Call only when:

        • Gamestate is GameState.PLAY1 or GameState.SPECIAL_BUILDING
        • ! (waitingForBankTradeMsg || waitingForTradeResponse)
        • ourPlayerData.getResources().contains(targetPieceResources)
        Since:
        1.1.08
        See Also:
        placeIfExpectPlacing()

      • planBuilding

        protected void planBuilding()
        Plan the next building plan and target. Should be called from run() under these conditions:
        ( !expectPLACING_ROBBER && buildingPlan.empty() && (ourPlayerData.getResources().getTotal() > 1) && (failedBuildingAttempts < MAX_DENIED_BUILDING_PER_TURN))

        Sets these fields and makes these calls:

        • SOCRobotDM.planStuff (FAST_STRATEGY or SMART_STRATEGY)
        • buildingPlan
        • lastTarget
        • SOCRobotNegotiator.setTargetPiece(int, SOCPossiblePiece)
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handlePLAYERELEMENTS

        protected void handlePLAYERELEMENTS(SOCPlayerElements mes)
        Handle a PLAYERELEMENTS for this game. See #handlePLAYERELEMENT(SOCPlayer, int, int, PEType, int) for actions taken.
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • handlePLAYERELEMENT

        protected void handlePLAYERELEMENT(SOCPlayerElement mes)
        Handle a PLAYERELEMENT for this game. See #handlePLAYERELEMENT(SOCPlayer, int, int, PEType, int) for actions taken.
        Since:
        1.1.08

      • handlePLAYERELEMENT

        protected void handlePLAYERELEMENT(SOCPlayer pl,
                                   int pn,
                                   int action,
                                   SOCPlayerElement.PEType etype,
                                   int amount)
        Handle a player information update from a SOCPlayerElement or SOCPlayerElements message: Update a player's amount of a resource or a building type.

        If this during the GameState.ROLL_OR_CARD state, then update the SOCRobotNegotiator's is-selling flags.

        If our player is losing a resource needed for the buildingPlan, clear the plan if this is for the Special Building Phase (on the 6-player board). In normal game play, we clear the building plan at the start of each turn.

        Otherwise, only the game data is updated, nothing brain-specific.

        Parameters:
        pl - Player to update; some elements take null. If null and pn != -1, will find pl using game.getPlayer(pn).
        pn - Player number from message (sometimes -1 for none or all)
        action - SOCPlayerElement.SET, GAIN, or LOSE
        etype - Element type, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.NUMKNIGHTS
        amount - The new value to set, or the delta to gain/lose
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • handlePLAYERELEMENT_numRsrc

        protected void handlePLAYERELEMENT_numRsrc(SOCPlayer pl,
                                           int action,
                                           int rtype,
                                           java.lang.String rtypeStr,
                                           int amount)
        Update a player's amount of a resource.
        • If this is a SOCPlayerElement.LOSE action, and the player does not have enough of that type, the rest are taken from the player's UNKNOWN amount.
        • If we are losing from type UNKNOWN, first convert player's known resources to unknown resources (individual amount information will be lost), then remove mes's unknown resources from player.
        • If this is a SET action, and it's for our own robot player, check the amount against ourPlayerData, and debug print if they don't match already.

        If our player is losing a resource needed for the buildingPlan, clear the plan if this is for the Special Building Phase (on the 6-player board). In normal game play, we clear the building plan at the start of each turn.

        Before v2.0.00 this method directly took a SOCPlayerElement instead of that message's action and amount fields.

        Parameters:
        pl - Player to update
        action - SOCPlayerElement.SET, GAIN, or LOSE
        rtype - Type of resource, like SOCResourceConstants.CLAY
        rtypeStr - Resource type name, for debugging
        amount - The new value to set, or the delta to gain/lose
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • trackNewSettlement

        protected void trackNewSettlement(SOCSettlement newSettlement,
                                  boolean isCancel)
        Run a newly placed settlement through the playerTrackers. Called only after SOCGame.putPiece(SOCPlayingPiece) or SOCGame.putTempPiece(SOCPlayingPiece).

        During initial board setup, settlements aren't tracked when placed. They are deferred until their corresponding road placement, in case a human player decides to cancel their settlement and place it elsewhere. During normal play, the settlements are tracked immediately when placed. (Code previously in body of the run method.) Placing the code in its own method allows tracking that settlement when the road's putPiece message arrives.

        Parameters:
        newSettlement - The newly placed settlement for the playerTrackers
        isCancel - Is this our own robot's settlement placement, rejected by the server? If so, this method call will cancel its placement within the game data / robot data.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • trackNewCity

        protected void trackNewCity(SOCCity newCity,
                            boolean isCancel)
        Run a newly placed city through the PlayerTrackers.
        Parameters:
        newCity - The newly placed city
        isCancel - Is this our own robot's city placement, rejected by the server? If so, this method call will cancel its placement within the game data / robot data.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • trackNewRoadOrShip

        protected void trackNewRoadOrShip(SOCRoutePiece newPiece,
                                  boolean isCancel)
        Run a newly placed road or ship through the playerTrackers.

        Before v2.0.00 this method was trackNewRoad.

        Parameters:
        newPiece - The newly placed road or ship
        isCancel - Is this our own robot's placement, rejected by the server? If so, this method call will cancel its placement within the game data / robot data.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • cancelWrongPiecePlacement

        protected void cancelWrongPiecePlacement(SOCCancelBuildRequest mes)
        We've asked for an illegal piece placement. Cancel and invalidate this planned piece, make a new plan. If SOCGame.isSpecialBuilding(), will set variables to force the end of our special building turn. Also handles illegal requests to buy development cards (piece type -2 in SOCCancelBuildRequest).

        Must update game data by calling SOCGame.setGameState(GameState) before calling this method.

        This method increments failedBuildingAttempts, but won't leave the game if we've failed too many times. The brain's run loop should make that decision.

        • If SOCGame.getGameState() is GameState.PLAY1, server likely denied us due to resources, not due to building plan being interrupted by another player's building before our special building phase. (Could also be due to a bug in the chosen building plan.) Will clear our building plan so we'll make a new one.
        • In other gamestates, assumes requested piece placement location was illegal. Will call cancelWrongPiecePlacementLocal(SOCPlayingPiece) so we don't try again to build there.
        • Either way, sends a CancelBuildRequest message to the server.
        Parameters:
        mes - Cancel message from server, including piece type
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • cancelWrongPiecePlacementLocal

        protected void cancelWrongPiecePlacementLocal(SOCPlayingPiece cancelPiece)
        Remove our incorrect piece placement, it's been rejected by the server. Take this piece out of trackers, without sending any response back to the server.

        This method invalidates that piece in trackers, so we don't try again to build there. Since we treat it like another player's new placement, we can remove any of our planned pieces depending on this one.

        Calls resetBuildingPlan(). Also calls SOCPlayer.clearPotentialSettlement(int), clearPotentialRoad, or clearPotentialCity. During Initial Placement states <= GameState.START3B, calls OpeningBuildStrategy.cancelWrongPiecePlacement(SOCPlayingPiece).

        Parameters:
        cancelPiece - Type and coordinates of the piece to cancel; null is allowed but not very useful.
        Since:
        1.1.00

      • kill

        public void kill()
        Kill this brain's thread: clears its "alive" flag, stops pinger, puts a null message into the event queue.

      • pause

        public void pause(int msec)
        pause for a bit.

        When SOCGame.isBotsOnly, pause only 25% as long, to quicken the simulation but not make it too fast to allow a person to observe. Can change BOTS_ONLY_FAST_PAUSE_FACTOR to adjust that percentage.

        In a 6-player game, pause only 75% as long, to shorten the overall game delay, except if waitingForTradeResponse. This is indicated by the pauseFaster flag.

        Parameters:
        msec - number of milliseconds to pause

      • placeFirstSettlement

        protected void placeFirstSettlement(int firstSettlement)
        place planned first settlement
        Parameters:
        firstSettlement - First settlement's node coordinate
        See Also:
        placeInitSettlement(int)

      • placeInitSettlement

        protected void placeInitSettlement(int initSettlement)
        Place planned initial settlement after first one.
        Parameters:
        initSettlement - Second or third settlement's node coordinate, from OpeningBuildStrategy.planSecondSettlement() should not be -1
        See Also:
        placeFirstSettlement(int)

      • planAndPlaceInitRoad

        protected void planAndPlaceInitRoad()
        Plan and place a road attached to our most recently placed initial settlement, in game states START1B, START2B, START3B. Calls OpeningBuildStrategy.planInitRoad().

        Road choice is based on the best nearby potential settlements, and doesn't directly check ourPlayerData.isPotentialRoad(edgeCoord). If the server rejects our road choice, bot will call cancelWrongPiecePlacementLocal(SOCPlayingPiece) which will call OpeningBuildStrategy.cancelWrongPiecePlacement(SOCPlayingPiece) in case the OBS wants to take action to prevent re-choosing the same wrong choice again, like clearing the potential settlement node we were aiming for.

      • moveRobber

        protected void moveRobber()
        Select a new robber location and move the robber there. Calls RobberStrategy.getBestRobberHex(). Calls SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.moveRobber(SOCGame, SOCPlayer, int).

        Currently the robot always chooses to move the robber, never the pirate.

      • discard

        protected void discard(int numDiscards)
        Select resources to discard, then ask the server to do so. Calls DiscardStrategy.discard(int, SOCBuildPlanStack). Calls SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient.discard(SOCGame, SOCResourceSet).

        This method can be overridden if a bot's discard code needs to do something outside the scope of the DiscardStrategy method, like send messages to the server before or after the discard request.

        Parameters:
        numDiscards - Number of resources bot's been asked to discard
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • tradeWithBank

        protected boolean tradeWithBank(SOCBuildPlan buildPlan)
        Make bank trades or port trades to get the required resources for executing a plan, if possible. Calls SOCRobotNegotiator.getOfferToBank(SOCBuildPlan, SOCResourceSet).

        Before v2.4.50 this method was tradeToTarget2(SOCResourceSet).

        Parameters:
        buildPlan - Build plan to look for resources to build. getOfferToBank(..) will typically call SOCBuildPlan.getFirstPieceResources() to determine the resources we want. Can be null or an empty plan (returns false).
        Returns:
        true if we sent a request to trade, false if we already have the resources or if we don't have enough to trade in for buildPlan's required resources.

      • considerOffer

        protected int considerOffer(SOCTradeOffer offer)
        Consider a trade offer made by another player. If offered to our player, calls SOCRobotNegotiator.considerOffer2(SOCTradeOffer, int).
        Parameters:
        offer - the offer to consider
        Returns:
        a code from SOCRobotNegotiator that represents how we want to respond: IGNORE_OFFER, ACCEPT_OFFER, REJECT_OFFER, or COUNTER_OFFER. Note: any negative value returned means we do nothing (IGNORE_OFFER).
        See Also:
        makeCounterOffer(SOCTradeOffer)

      • makeOffer

        protected boolean makeOffer(SOCBuildPlan buildPlan)
        Make a trade offer to another player, or decide to make no offer. Calls SOCRobotNegotiator.makeOffer(SOCBuildPlan). Will set either waitingForTradeResponse or doneTrading, and update ourPlayerData.setCurrentOffer(),

        Before v2.4.50 this method took a SOCPossiblePiece, not a SOCBuildPlan.

        Parameters:
        buildPlan - our current build plan
        Returns:
        true if we made an offer

      • makeCounterOffer

        protected boolean makeCounterOffer(SOCTradeOffer offer)
        Plan a counter offer to another player, and make it from our client. Calls SOCRobotNegotiator.makeCounterOffer(SOCTradeOffer), then ourPlayerData.setCurrentOffer(..) with the result or null. Updates waitingForTradeResponse flag. If no counteroffer is made here, sets doneTrading.
        Parameters:
        offer - the other player's offer
        Returns:
        true if we made and sent a counteroffer

      • clearTradingFlags

        public void clearTradingFlags(boolean isBankTrade,
                              boolean wasAllowed)
        Clears all flags waiting for a bank or player trade message. waitingForTradeResponse, waitingForBankTradeMsg, any flags added in a third-party robot brain.
        Parameters:
        isBankTrade - True if was bank/port trade, not player trade
        wasAllowed - True if trade was successfully offered, completed, or rejected; false if server sent a message disallowing it
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        tradeStopWaitingClearOffer(), handleTradeResponse(int, boolean)

      • startTurnMainActions

        protected void startTurnMainActions()
        Perform any specific actions needed by this brain at start of the main part of any player's turn: Dice roll actions are done, game state just became GameState.PLAY1.

        Default behaviour: No special actions. Third-party bots may override this stub.

        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        endTurnActions()

      • endTurnActions

        protected boolean endTurnActions()
        Perform any specific actions needed by this brain just before ending their own turn, which may result in continuing their turn for a little while.

        If returns true, caller will call resetFieldsAtEndTurn().

        Is called only after considerScenarioTurnFinalActions() returns false.

        Default behaviour: Always end turn immediately. Third-party bots may override this stub.

        Returns:
        true if can end turn, false otherwise
        Since:
        2.4.50
        See Also:
        startTurnMainActions()
